word.entryDescription: things you do not want and throw away
word.entryExample: Look at all this rubbish in the kitchen!

word.entryDescription: not polite; impolite
word.entryExample: Michael thinks it is rude to just drop in without phoning first.

word.entryDescription: a carpet that only covers part of the floor
word.entryExample: There's a rug next to the bed.

word.entryDescription: a team sport in which people carry an oval ball and try to place it across a line
word.entryExample: Rugby players often suffer from knee problems.

word.entryDescription: (also ruins) the damaged remain of an old building
word.entryExample: Older cities tend to have buildings of historic interest at their centre, such as castles, palaces or ruins.

word.entryDescription: an instruction which tells you what should be done and what is and is not allowed
word.entryExample: We shouldn't use our phones during the day, unless it's an emergency. It's a school rule!

word.entryDescription: a thing you use to draw straight lines and measure things
word.entryExample: I carry my ruler in a pencil case.

word.entryDescription: to move more quickly than walking using your legs
word.entryExample: I like to run in the park.

word.entryDescription: to escape
word.entryExample: Run away from the cat, little mouse!

word.entryDescription: to use all of something and have nothing left
word.entryExample: The car has broken down and we've run out of petrol.

word.entryDescription: somebody who runs, especially in races
word.entryExample: Who's your favourite runner?

word.entryDescription: an activity in which you run
word.entryExample: He likes running.

word.entryDescription: water that is supplied to a building through pipes
word.entryExample: Sophie used to miss having a bath and hot running water.

word.entryDescription: when your nose has liquid coming out of it
word.entryExample: If you've got a runny nose, there are some tissues over there.

word.entryDescription: a large strong bag used for storing and carrying food or goods
word.entryExample: The flour is put into sacks and then loaded onto the lorries.

word.entryDescription: not happy
word.entryExample: Don't be sad, I'll tell you a funny story.

word.entryDescription: a metal pin for fastening things together; it has a point at one end and a cover at the other into which the pointed end fits
word.entryExample: You need to hold it together with a safety pin.

word.entryDescription: to control a boat which has a large cloth attached to a tall pole, and is pushed by the wind
word.entryExample: Would you like to sail around the world?

word.entryDescription: a sport or activity in which people sail boats
word.entryExample: The weather is great so let's go sailing on the lake.

word.entryDescription: a dish of mixed vegetables which you eat raw
word.entryExample: I'd like tomato and cucumber salad, please.

word.entryDescription: a fixed amount of money paid to an employee usually monthly
word.entryExample: Sandra will be paid a salary for her job at the magazine.

word.entryDescription: an event in a shop when there are lots of discounts
word.entryExample: Let's go shopping!. The department store is having a sale this week.

word.entryDescription: a fairly large fish with silver skin and pink flesh, which lives both in the sea and in fresh water
word.entryExample: I'll have the pan-fried salmon please.

word.entryDescription: a white powder made from a mineral, used to give flavour to food
word.entryExample: We've got salt here, but we haven't got any pepper. Can you bring some, please?

word.entryDescription: tasting of salt
word.entryExample: Crisps taste really salty.

word.entryDescription: a type of hot spicy Indian food made from meat or vegetables covered in thin pastry and cooked in hot oil
word.entryExample: Lunch could be a sandwich, but it's just as likely to be a samosa or sushi.

word.entryDescription: the very small fine pieces of rock that you find on beaches and in deserts
word.entryExample: They are playing with the sand.

word.entryDescription: a light comfortable shoe worn in warm weather
word.entryExample: I have to buy a new pair of sandals for the summer.

word.entryDescription: strong wind in the desert that blows a lot of sand in the air
word.entryExample: Besides the extreme heat, sandstorms are the most terrifying features of the desert.

word.entryDescription: two pieces of bread with other food between them
word.entryExample: I take sandwiches to work every day.

word.entryDescription: a cooking appliance used for toasting sandwiches
word.entryExample: We need a new sandwich maker.

word.entryDescription: conditions related to supplying water for drinking and dealing with waste
word.entryExample: World leaders should invest in tackling air pollution and improving water sanitation, particularly in countries with rapidly developing economies.

word.entryDescription: a long piece of cloth that you wrap around your body like a dress, worn especially by women in Southern Asia
word.entryExample: Saris can be up to 9 metres long.

word.entryDescription: a loose skirt consisting of a long piece of cloth wrapped around your waist, worn by men and women of Malaysia and many Pacific islands
word.entryExample: Men from Java often wear sarongs during religious or casual occasions.

word.entryDescription: past simple and past participle form of 'sit' – to be or get supported by your bottom on a flat surface while the top half of your body remains upright
word.entryExample: Have you ever sat in a fire engine?

word.entryDescription: extremely wet; soaked
word.entryExample: Too much rain can cause the ground to become saturated.

word.entryDescription: a round metal container with a handle, used for cooking
word.entryExample: Fill a saucepan with water.

word.entryDescription: a food made of very small pieces of meat inside a skin (=a thin long bag)
word.entryExample: Can I have a sausage for breakfast, please?

word.entryDescription: flat grasslands found especially in Africa
word.entryExample: Why don't forests grow on the savanna?

word.entryDescription: to not waste something or to keep something for the future
word.entryExample: I bring sandwiches to work because I'm trying to save money.

word.entryDescription: to store a file on some permanent medium such as a hard drive, a CD-ROM, or a memory stick
word.entryExample: Save your work by saving a file.

word.entryDescription: to keep money instead of spending it, especially in order to buy a particular thing
word.entryExample: I need to save up for my next trip.

word.entryDescription: past simple form of 'save' – to make a computer keep the work that you have done on it; for example by putting it on a disk
word.entryExample: Fortunately, Sandra's laptop stopped working after she had saved all her work.

word.entryDescription: (plural 'savings') money that you have saved, especially in a bank, etc.
word.entryExample: I wanted to look at my online savings account and print out my statement.

word.entryDescription: salty or spicy; not sweet
word.entryExample: I prefer the taste of savoury foods, like cheese, to sweet ones.

word.entryDescription: past simple form of 'see' – to sense something with your eyes
word.entryExample: I saw a great film at the weekend.

word.entryDescription: to express something in words
word.entryExample: Say "good morning".

word.entryDescription: a well-known phrase or statement
word.entryExample: The saying 'People without vision perish' means that people without imagination don't prosper.

word.entryDescription: a device used for weighing things
word.entryExample: You can measure weight with scales.

word.entryDescription: to use a scanner in order to copy a picture and put it in the memory of a computer
word.entryExample: Could you explain me how to scan a picture, please?
